Disillusioned, the taii'maku withdrew to their Illus, seeking solace in knowledge and solitude. During the Imperial Age, Emperor Baleroth attempted to gain access to the taii'maku's magical and engineering expertise but was met with resistance. This covert persecution only exacerbated their isolationist tendencies and mistrust of other species. The Kemet Invasion marked a turning point. The Illus endured relentless assaults, and Tanares heroes and taii'maku champions provided crucial support. This siege exposed the dangers of isolation, prompting taii'maku heroes to persuade their people to reconnect and exchange knowledge with other species. Gradually, the Illus reintegrated into a broader network of commerce and intellectual collaboration. Today, the taii'maku navigate the intricate politics of the realms, striving to protect their secrets and uphold their values. Some Illus remain independent, while others form alliances or openly support factions. Many have joined the Allied Forces, exploring new strategies to fight the Ungods. Although they yearn for cooperative endeavors, the taii'maku encounter challenges from unpredictable behavior and conflicting agendas among various factions. Their councils maintain vigilance against espionage and deceit, working to safeguard taii'maku secrets. Despite these hurdles, they persist in strengthening their repositories of knowledge. In recent times, the taii'maku have assisted in developing infrastructure across numerous human cities, particularly within the Republic and the Tanarean Empire. Their excep tional construction and engineering expertise have vastly improved the quality of life in these regions. They have al so established a nuanced relationship with the Magocracy of Mage Tower, engaging in lively debates and exchanging wisdom with their mages. However, the taii'maku remain wary, expressing concerns about the ethical implications of certain experiments conducted by the Magocracy.

trait.name: Contributing to a Better World
trait.text: The taii'maku stand in Tanares as architects of progress, tirelessly striving to forge a harmonious existence for all inhabitants. Their commitment to innovation and progress has given rise to astonishing constructs that seamlessly perform tasks, ensuring transportation, security, and unwavering support in their quest for an idyllic society. Masters of their craft, the taii'maku have achieved seemingly impossible feats: quenching the parched desert with life-giving water, taming the fury of unyielding floods, and constructing sophisticated sanitation systems. Their ingenious roadways bridge the gaps between cities and kingdoms, fostering unity and cooperation in the face of adversity. Taii'maku cities serve as radiant beacons of their grand vision, with constructs assuming the mantle of manual labor, allowing the citizens to immerse themselves in contemplation, research, and personal growth. Massive mechanical wagons and swift-flying vessels transport people with ease, while constructs dutifully cater to every conceivable task. In their pursuit of a brighter future, the taii'maku remain ever vigilant against the persistent menace of the kikoku. With unwavering resolve, they thwart these sinister creatures' attempts to reproduce and breach their resplendent cities. The taii'maku wield wisdom and reason as formidable weapons, serving as advisors and guides in a world beset by strife and corruption. Their most gifted strategists and thinkers labor tirelessly to craft intricate plans and tactics to counter the insidious influence of the Ungods, extending aid and warnings to other realms, even when their words fall on deaf ears. Through their steadfast dedication to logic and unyielding resistance to the vices and temptations of the Ungods, the taii'maku emerge as a formidable adversary in the battle against malevolent forces. Their very existence presents a challenge that the Ungods are all too eager to eliminate, yet the taii'maku remain undeterred, resolute in their mission to unite and uplift the denizens of Tanares.

trait.name: Taii'maku Society
trait.text: In the heart of the taii'maku civilization, a steadfast dedication to logic, rationality, and the pursuit of knowledge beats like a resonant drum. Eschewing traditional faith in deities, they perceive gods as highly evolved entities, masters of profound wisdom and comprehension of reality. Within their ranks, clerics and paladins exist, but they view them selves as emissaries of superior wisdom rather than servants of a divine being. The essence of taii'maku culture lies in order and balance, reflected by their harmonious, symmetrical, and geometric city architecture. Crafted with meticulous accuracy, their urban landscapes optimize mystical energy efficiency and resource management. Their cuisine, mirroring their methodical nature, emphasizes objectivity and efficiency over taste and presentation, crafting meals that deliver optimal health and nutrient intake. In their relationships, the taii'maku exhibit an extraordinary form of empathy. Devoid of emotional experience, it stems from understanding the logical and practical needs of others. Their ethical framework originates from a deep thought experiment in which they shed all knowledge of identity, status, and personal circumstances to impartially inhabit the lives of every individual. This process allows them to grasp the needs and perspectives of all beings, forging an ethical rule that is equitable and just for all. Such an approach is vital for the taii'maku to create a society that caters to everyone's needs without succumbing to oppression or tyranny. In pursuit of this ideal, they strive for a harmonious societal balance, ensuring the well-being of all without sacrificing the few. Every voice is heard and respected, fostering unity and shared understanding. Marriage in taii'maku society is deemed a logical obligation and lifelong commitment. Couples are selected based on intellectual compatibility and the potential to counter balance each other's weaknesses, resulting in partners with vastly different skill sets. When raising children, taii'maku parents display a profound sense of responsibility, attentive ness, and devotion, particularly in education and imparting wisdom. However, their parenting approach lacks the emotional warmth observed in other species. Society is structured around a knowledge-based hierarchy, with an individual's status determined by their contributions to collective wisdom. Their economy revolves around trading knowledge and bauronite ore, prioritizing the exchange of information, discoveries, ideas, and components for crafts and research over traditional gold coins. This system nurtures a culture of perpetual learning and innovation. Taii'maku governance is anchored in public councils led by the eldest members, inviting anyone with a contribution to engage in discussions. Decisions are made through vot ing, emphasizing logic over personal biases and frequently resulting in unanimous or near-unanimous outcomes, as they discuss until every individual is satisfied. The deep Taii'maku language, comprised of intricate symbols and exact mathematical forms, enables efficient and meticulous idea exchanges, unparalleled in Tanares. In leisure, they partake in intellectual debates, exchanging logical arguments to persuade their audience, or team sports that demand exceptional coordination and tactics.

trait.name: Math, Engineering, and Constructs
trait.text: Within the great halls of the taii'maku civilization, an un paralleled mastery of mathematics, engineering, and magic reverberates through every aspect of their intricate culture. This extraordinary fusion breathes life into a myriad of con structs, each pulsating with the volatile yet potent mystical energies of bauronite. Highly advanced constructs serve as the lifeblood of taii'maku society, ceaselessly fulfilling a diverse array of roles. From performing menial tasks and physical labor to acting as speedy vehicles, these constructs enable the taii'maku to dedicate their time to intellectual pursuits. Sentinel constructs vigilantly patrol the cities, responding to taii'maku commands and maintaining unwavering security. Transportation constructs range from horse-sized golems and massive mechanical wagons to soaring aerial machines and even city-sized, mobile Illus. The zenith of taii'maku engineering culminates in the impressive Giant Defenders, colossal constructs that rival the tallest giants and safeguard the Illus from ever-present threats. Yet, all taii'maku constructs necessitate fastidious maintenance to stave off corruption from their bauronite cores, which, if left unchecked, could render them uncontrollable and perilous. The taii'maku's resolute devotion to order, balance, and precision, coupled with their reverence for knowledge, forms the bedrock of their unique capabilities. They alone possess the aptitude to craft such remarkable constructs. Their culture fosters an environment that encourages ceaseless learning and innovation, transforming these constructs into more than just feats of engineering; they stand as emblematic representations of the taii'maku's relentless pursuit of progress. U'Tibam, the most eminent taii'maku mind of his era, epitomizes their exceptional intellect. His groundbreaking contributions to mathematics and the creation of the mightiest giant construct ever forged, a pivotal weapon against the Kemet Invasion, further highlight the taii'maku's ingenuity. The Illus frequently find themselves in need of specific resources to further their research or repair their constructs, often enlisting the aid of intrepid adventurers to procure the rare materials they require. Taii'Maku cities also tirelessly search for spies and purloined information or artifacts, offering bountiful rewards for their safe recovery. Prioritizing security above all else, the taii'maku remain perpetually vigilant for signs of infiltration, as the secrets of their constructs' creation and operation must be fiercely safeguarded.

trait.name: Mathematical Approach to Magic
trait.text: In the arcane domain, the taii'maku stand as a testament to their revolutionary theories that intricately weave the tapestry of magic with the threads of mathematics. This matchless approach births the crafting of impeccably precise magic circles and potent enchanted artifacts, transcending the symbolic renderings typically employed by their wizardly counterparts. The taii'maku spellcasters envision the cosmos as bound by a set of logical principles that can be deciphered through mathematical expressions, deeming magic as an extension of the physical realm. This unique perspective enables them to interlace mathematics within their incantations, and as such, taii'maku wizards etch their spells as algebraic formulas in their grimoires, deeming conventional symbols to be cumbersome and inefficient. As bold adventurers embark on perilous journeys into the depths of time-forgotten ruins, they may chance upon ancient tomes inscribed by legendary taii'maku archmages or unearth enigmatic arcane mechanisms, both teeming with labyrinthine equations that call for the keen intellect of the most erudite taii'maku minds to decipher. As they navigate through the forsaken remnants of bygone Illus, they may unveil cryptic geometric patterns that cloak concealed chambers. Nestled within these shrouded sanctuaries, one may find elaborate taii'maku-crafted magic circles, poised to unleash formidable and mysterious forces. The taii'maku's unwavering belief in a world that is inherently logical and mathematically harmonious drives their relentless pursuit of transcending the limitations of the arcane. Through their groundbreaking amalgamation of mathematics and mysticism, they forge breathtaking spells, enchanted relics, and wondrous contraptions imbued with unparalleled potency. It is their fervent aspiration to harness these mystical creations to reshape the world for the better.

trait.name: Taii'maku Names
trait.text:
Taii'makian words usually consist of short syllables with hard consonants that are pronounced with one's jaws closed, creating a distinct sound that other species hardly ever re produce correctly. The words often sound harsh or rough. Their last names sometimes represent the city they hail from, with the addition of an adjective representing their personal purpose. To facilitate communication, the taii'maku may present themselves to other species only by their first name, keeping their full name for themselves.
Male Names: A'Kole, B'Abku, B'Ogaji, B'Un, C'Hakado, D'Alolo, D'Umikole, E'Boko, E'Dowu, E'Ntun, G'Honk, G'Ombo, J'Aborii, J'Oawari, K'Antobu, K'Obbimbe, K'Onego, K'Oyode, K'Uwako, L'Amumbo, M'Antuna, M'Bollo, N'Ingolo, O'Bimbolo, O'Kashar, O'Ketokunbo, O'Lujime, T'Hanlu, U'Chenno, Z'Hantan, Z'Ouwanga.
Female Names: A'Beba, A'Deuga, A'Isha, A'Laba, A'Yodela, B'Alan, B'Ennah, B'Onbya, B'Usari, C'Honwalla, D'Ainoka, D'Aljih, E'Nla, E'Thuhole, F'Alizah, G'Ainda, J'Ahali, K'Akilih, K'Anyeta, K'Azanatti, K'Oomanni, L'Atesha, L'Ifanni, M'Olaika, N'Aan, U'Gocha, V'Ulah, W'Anjika, Y'Eeja, Z'Alan.
Last Names: Alaabo (protector), Alaafia (peace), Apata (rock), Asa (shield), Asale (desert), Enjini (engine), Eranko (animal), Ewa (beauty), Ianryn (sand), Ibimo (birth), Idan (magic), Igbagbo (faith), Igbesi (life), Iho (cave), Iji (storm), Iku (death), Imole (light), Irinajo (travel), Iseda (nature), Ja (fight), Koeko (learn), Lagbara (strong), Nla (great), Ododo (flower), Ogo (club), Ojo (day), Oke (mountain), Ona (way), Oorun (sun), Sode (hunt).

trait.name: Age
trait.text: The taii'makus experience a swift maturation, concluding childhood at 8 years and achieving adulthood at the age of 16. Rarely do they live past the age of 80.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Most taii'maku are lawful, holding strong beliefs in the systems and laws of their Ilus. They tend to neutrality over good and evil, keeping their personal beliefs to themselves for the greater good of society.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Taii'maku are taller than humans, standing well over 6 to 7 feet tall and averaging 210 to 250 pounds. Your size is Medium.

trait.name: Historical Nomadism
trait.text: You gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: History or Survival.

trait.name: Strong Hands
trait.text: Endowed with six fingers, taii'makus possess enhanced hand strength. You have advantage on Strength (Athletics) checks related to climbing and saving throws against disarming effects.

trait.name: Mathematical Mind
trait.text: The unique and logical thought pro cess of the taii'maku grant them an edge with numbers and math. You have advantage on all ability checks directly in volving mathematical or accounting tasks.

trait.name: Mind Inclination
trait.text: Rather than subspecies, taii'maku display dispositions inclined either towards Philosophy, with a comprehensive approach, or Engineering, focusing on specific areas of study.

trait.name: Inclination to Engineering
trait.text: Taii'maku who choose to follow the math and engineering way are extremely focused, becoming the best at what they propose to be. In search of constant improvement in what they have chosen, they are even rough with what does not involve their studies.

trait.name: Innate Engineers
trait.text: You are proficient with tinker's tools. Additionally, when analyzing a mechanism such as an automaton or a mechanical trap, you can attempt an Intelligence (Investigation) check to determine its purpose and function. If successful, you or creatures to whom you have explained the mechanism have advantage in ability checks made to use or disable it.

trait.name: Ingenious Inventors
trait.text:
Using tinker's tools, you can construct magical mechanisms. Spend 1 hour and 20 gp on materials to create a mechanism, limited to three at any given time. If you create a fourth, you must sever the magical connection with an existing one. When creating a mechanism, choose from the following options:
Extended vision monocle. This device lets you see better. While wearing it, your vision range doubles, and you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight. (Weight: 1)
Clock-compass. This item always shows you the exact time and which way is north. (Weight: 0)
Sound amplifier. This device helps you hear better. You have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing. Alternatively, you can use it to amplify your voice so it can be heard twice as far. (Weight: 1)
Foldable glider. This item allows you to slow your fall and move forward. For every 5 feet you fall, you can move forward up to 5 feet reducing this distance from the fall, as long as you have enough space. If you can't move forward you take the remaining damage as normal. (Weight: 4)
Mechanical thrower. This item lets you throw a weapon or improvised weapon 10 feet farther than normal. (Weight: 1)
Automatic reloader. This item lets you ignore the loading property of a ranged weapon you are wielding twice, recovering its uses on a short rest. (Weight: 2)
Jumper. This gadget allows you to make extraordinary leaps. While wearing it, your jump range doubles, and you have advantage on Strength (Athletics) checks related to jumping. (Weight: 1)
Climber. This item allows you to climb easily. While wearing it, climbing does not cost you extra movement, and you have advantage on Strength (Athletics) checks related to climbing. (Weight: 1)
Carrying frame. This set of springs and gears helps you carry more weight. While wearing it, you are considered to have +3 to your Strength ability score for the purposes of calculating load and lifting weight, as well as for the Strength requirements of armor. (Weight: 3)
Potion injector. This contraption allows you to load a potion into a mounted reservoir at the end of a long rest. As a bonus action, you can inject the loaded potion directly into your bloodstream and receive its effects. (Weight: 2)

trait.name: Languages
trait.text:
You can speak, read, and write Common and Taii'makian.
The Taii'makian language is known for its hard syllables and closed-jaw pronunciation, traits that the taii'maku often apply to other tongues they know. Taii'makian runes, made up of geometric shapes, represent words and concepts; by combining up to four runes, a greater concept is created, resembling a sentence in Common. Foreigners often view these lines and markings as complicated mechanical sketches.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
"As soon as he reached home, Geppetto took his tools and began to cut and shape the wood into a Marionette." —Carlo Collodi, Le Avventure di Pinocchio
Ever a joy to children, geppettin resemble living playthings made of wood, cloth, or porcelain. Though easily mistaken for puppets, geppettin aren't manipulated by a just-out-of-sight puppeteer; they are animated, sentient, and independent.
Bisque geppettin are a form of porcelain doll, crafted with exacting specification and luxurious clothing materials. Though they are designed to look as realistic as possible, they are certainly the most terrifying of geppettin due to their lifeless visage. Though their faces are often very fragile, their construction is generally much hardier than their brethren's.
Source: Valda's Spire of Secrets p. 8 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Living Toys
trait.text: As a race, the geppettin are an oddity. Though rare, they are numerous enough and share enough similarities that they may be counted as an actual race of people, and not merely freak mishaps of magic. While there might be dedicated creators of geppettin, as there are with golems, many geppettin come to life on their own. Physically, geppettin are often shorter than halflings. Their physical features vary greatly from type to type, but they are almost always humanoid in shape. For simplicity, geppettin are classified by their materials: bisque are porcelain, marionettes are wood, and plushies are made of fabric. Despite being made of somewhat flimsy materials, sentience grants them an odd hardiness. Additionally, due to their non-living nature, they never hunger, rarely tire, and are adept at being innocuous. Most find some form of work or profession in entertainment, but a few find fantastic success as spies and assassins.

trait.name: Geppettin Names
trait.text:
Like other constructs, geppettin rarely name themselves. Typically, a construct has no conception that living creatures obsessively name everything, and have a name bestowed upon them—in this case, geppettin are normally named by children, or are given terms of endearment by adults.
Names: Birdie, Cuddles, Desmond, Dusty, Hobbes, Fluffie, Frowny, Lizzie, Patches, Princess, Pup-pup, Red Jacket, Teddy

trait.name: Ability Score Increases
trait.text:
Increase one ability score of your choice by 2 and increase a different score by 1, or increase three different scores by 1.
Typical: Dexterity +1, Constitution +1, Charisma +1

trait.name: Age
trait.text: As living constructs, geppettin don't age, and are mature as soon as they become sentient.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Geppettin, as varied as they are, run the gamut of alignments. Plushies are generally good, bisques tend towards evil, and marionettes are usually in between.

trait.name: Creature Type
trait.text: You are a Humanoid. However, spells and effects that specifically affect Constructs affect you as well.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: You are Small.

trait.name: Darkvision
trait.text: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of yourself as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of gray.

trait.name: Construct Anatomy
trait.text: You are immune to nonmagical diseases. You don't need to eat or breathe, but you can ingest food and drink if you wish. You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep. You can finish a long rest by spending 4 hours in a motionless state, during which you retain consciousness.

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While you are motionless, you are indistinguishable from an ordinary porcelain doll.

trait.name: Sudden Strike
trait.text: Whenever you deal damage to a creature with a weapon attack roll on your first turn in combat, the creature takes extra damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

trait.name: Unnerving
trait.text: You gain proficiency in the Intimidation skill, and have advantage on any Charisma (Intimidation) rolls you make against a creature that hasn't previously seen you move.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: Your character can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your GM agree is appropriate.

trait.name: Adorable
trait.text: You gain proficiency in the Persuasion skill, and have advantage on Charisma (Persuasion) rolls you make against children or other humanoids that are fond of cute things.

trait.name: Stuffed With Fluff
trait.text: When you take bludgeoning damage, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to the damage, and you are also knocked 5 feet away from the source of the damage. You can't use this reaction if you can't be knocked away from the source of the damage.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: Your character can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your GM agree is appropriate.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
"It was an ancient thing of moss-covered wood which creaked like a greatoak as it breathed, but I'll never forget its eyes: those glowing points were a thing of the fey, a thing of the deep woods forgotten to man." —Faizon the Blue, encountering a mandrake
Laymen believe that mandrakes are wailing babies grown from the roots of a plant. However, such mandrakes are those which are harvested too early; literally children still in infancy. If allowed to grow for a year and a day before being harvested, mandrakes can mature into great and powerful tree people.
Source: Valda's Spire of Secrets p. 10 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Flesh from Wood
trait.text: With a skin of thick bark and leaves growing at their extremities, you could be forgiven for believing that mandrakes are simply bizarre plants, treants, or animated trees. This might even be partially true: it seems that while mandrakes originated from some plant ancestor, they have become something midway between animal and plant through strange magic or stranger evolution. Mandrake anatomies are filled with paradoxes. They bleed a ruby ichor, reminiscent of both blood and sap. Their hearts, which look like a knot of roots, pump this around their body, enriching it with oxygen borne by leaves and special pores on their extremities. By preference, mandrakes can bask in the sunlight or consume living things for nourishment, and can even absorb nutrients through their feet, though they rarely subsist by sunlight and water alone.

trait.name: Forest Envoys
trait.text: Alchemists and arcanists alike scratch their heads at mandrakes, but druids know them as the green emissaries who stand between the realms of animals and plants, making peace for all parties. To druidic tradition, mandrakes are unique, ancient constructions of Mother Nature herself, intended to act as delegates for her will. Mandrakes are credited by old druids for aligning elves with the forests and dwarves with the mountains; only with the rising tide of humanoids and their preponderance of gods did most creatures forget about Mother Nature and her half-plant ambassadors. Today, mandrakes are rare, and make their homes in the forests near where villages and cities meet the true wilds. Humans tell tales of mandrakes savaging those who enter their domain, but druids and those who respect the old traditions of the forest know that such ire is seldom undeserved.

trait.name: Mandrake Names
trait.text:
Taking their names from the old spirits of the forest, which have long been forgotten by men, mandrakes treat all names with great reverence.
Male Names: Akathaso, Bistonis, Cithaeron, Hathor, Nomina, Orseis, Othrys, Yggdras
Female Names: Argyra, Circe, Claea, Hadryade, Helike, Lauma, Moria, Thronia

trait.text: Mandrakes mature in a decade and live for centuries, growing wider and more gnarled with bark as they age.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Mandrakes are known to keep centuries-old concords known only to the oldest of creatures. Though they stay neutral in most matters, they tend to lean toward lawful alignments.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Mandrakes usually stand tall and slim, typically almost seven feet high, with spring mandrakes being smaller and winter mandrakes being slightly larger, and often hunched over. Your size is Medium.

trait.name: Plant Nature
trait.text: Even though you are not fully a plant, you still possess many of the same traits as one. As long as you are in direct sunlight for at least 4 hours a day, you don't need to eat. Additionally, you can breathe through your leaves and extremities and you can absorb water and nutrients through your feet.

trait.name: Emissary Of The Trees
trait.text: You are proficient in the Nature skill. Additionally, you have advantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks you make to interact with Beasts and Plants.

trait.name: Root Magic
trait.text: You know the shillelagh cantrip and can target yourself with the spell, treating one of your limbs as a club for the duration of the spell. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the goodberry spell with this trait, without requiring a material component. Starting at 5th level, you can cast the barkskin spell with this trait, without requiring a material component. Once you cast goodberry or barkskin with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast either of those spells using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells when you cast them with this trait (choose one when you select this race).

trait.name: Entangling Vines
trait.text:
You can use your bonus action to cause grasping weeds and vines to sprout up from the ground around a Large or smaller creature you can see within 30 feet. Until the end of the creature's next turn, its speed becomes 0 and can't increase. This effect ends early if the creature takes the Disengage action. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. When you reach 3rd level, your Entangling Vines gain an additional effect based on the season in which you were harvested (choose when you select this race):
Spring. Your Entangling Vines can target an airborne creature within 30 feet of the ground, which is pulled safely to the ground when you use this trait.
Summer. Your Entangling Vines can move the target up to 10 feet to an unoccupied space on the ground or on a floor.
Autumn. Your Entangling Vines can affect a second creature within 5 feet of the first target.
Winter. The target takes cold damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

trait.text:
"You laughed when I said I would repay you," said the Mouse. "Now you see that even a Mouse can help a Lion." -Aesop, The Lion and the Mouse
Never to be looked down upon, the slight, unassuming mousefolk are kindhearted to a fault and possess courage greater than most giants.
Source: Valda's Spire of Secrets p. 12 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Tiny But Brave
trait.text: Though the tiny, big-eared mousefolk are often overlooked by larger creatures, history is rife with stories of gallant mouse-knights staring down dragons, crossing blades with warlords, and charging into grand battles. It happens that few mousefolk aspire to heroism, but a certain moral compass often compels mousefolk to a higher cause. As a rule, mousefolk are good to their neighbors and rarely pick fights; after all, most people can be reasoned with. Those who can't be reasoned with, however, should rightly fear mousefolk striking at their knees. Mousefolk don't suffer bullies lightly. Despite their valorous legacies, no histories are written about the mousefolk culture itself. This i s because the mousefolk language, Rodentia, has no written form, and mousefolk preserve thier history in stories and songs passed from elders to children throughout the generations.

trait.name: Hooded or Disgraced
trait.text: Though ratlings have long abandoned the old ways, a mouseling is never to be seen without a hood. Following ancient tradition, mouselings wear hoods they have sewn themselves at all times, except in the most dire of circumstances. A hood is a symbol of wealth and social standing, and is sometimes replaced with hats or other headwear when appropriate. If a mouseling is seen without a hood, it is a sure sign of disgrace and exile, the most personal punishment a village of mouselings can inflict.

trait.name: Mousefolk Names
trait.text:

Male Names: Arven, Blodge, Dunfur, Frisk, Jinoree, Phrenik, Reep, Skapp
Female Names: Beeka, Constance, Juniper, Romsca, Serena, Tess, Wincey

"Hers was a kind of unearthly beauty that resisted the very confines of reality-hair so airy that it flowed in defiance of gravity, skin so fair that it could be seen through." —Jethro Meddlitt, gnome wizard, meeting a spirithost
Spirithosts are the eerie, spectral residents of the Border Ethereal. Though often confused for ghosts, spirithosts are very much alive-as much as their shifting, partly material bodies allow.
Source: Valda's Spire of Secrets p. 13 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Ethereal Progeny
trait.text: The Ethereal Plane is rightly believed to be the domain of restless, transient souls. However, the Border Ethereal, which lies closer to the Material Plane, has its fair share of adopted inhabitants, such as the blink dog and phase spider. Spirithosts are the only humanoids to have adpoted this plane, and might be considered its only true descendents. Though their bodies resemble that of ghostsslightly translucent and glowing with a pale, white light-spirithosts are not undead. Far from it: they are born, grow old, die, and can even raise children. Yet the stigma of undeath lingers over them. Many a well-meaning but ignorant cleric or paladin has tried to turn or banish a spirithost to no avail. To avoid such conflict, spirithosts often avoid large, unfamiliar towns, or disguise their ethereality from others. Spirithosts do not experience time in the same way as most mortal creatures. As a result, even though they mature in their teens, their lives can stretch on for hundreds of years.

trait.name: Spirithost Names
trait.text:

Female Names: Amias, Belias, Heathimis, Lethreas, Nix'silia, Priscilla, Sayu, Shavaras, Sunda, Wishnas

Humans are known for being ambitious, diverse, and extremely short-lived, but also have the dubious honor of having an abundance of near-human offshoots, for it seems humans can breed with just about anything. Near-humans are still basically humans, bearing subtly different traits from a wide variety of sources, and are individually rare but make up a surprisingly large portion of any human population. Near-humans come in all shapes and sizes and from all walks of life. They are the barest expression of human diversity: human offshoots from all corners of the world.
One of your parents was a human and the other was a dwarf. Such a pairing is unlikely to have produced offspring, but you have defied the odds to join the ranks of the sturdy and resilient muls.
Source: Valda's Spire of Secrets p. 16 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Hastily the frazzled human scrambled down the alleyway. He was the king of the back pathways, and none would dare challenge him. None, except the thing that now trailed behind him. A creature of nightmares. A Fallen. A monstrosity with a body of flames. He cuts left, then right. But still he hears the footsteps behind him. And in no time, the monster's light covers his whole body. This was the end. He knew it.
The vampire delighted himself, draining the blood from the foolish adventurer that thought that she alone could end his empire. As he did, the blood's taste felt foul, even for an undead. The corpse of the fallen warrior started to convulse with shadows darkening her skin, covering her completely. The vampire jumped a few steps back, trembling in fear knowing what was happening. The Tiefling got up and simply stared at the monster that had killed her, creating a sword out of the shadows from her new body.
The Fallen, a people who were brought back to life by non-traditional means. They weren't resurrected by a powerful spell caster, divine intervention or by a necromancy ritual, but by their own raw emotions. Anger. Failure. Fulfillment. Pride and Revenge; All feelings which can alter the course of someone's life are enough to bring back another, and even more powerful than before.
The representation of resurrection by anger. Being revived by the most negative emotion brings the most negative effects over the Fallen's body. Being nothing but bones, necromancy thrives within them. They are often mistaken for simple mindless skeletons, even by other reanimated undead.
Source: Fallen by Blue4Eternety p. 3 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Living Emotions
trait.text:
A Fallen's memory persists when reanimated, the transformation and awakening from their previous race into their current state took barely an instant from their point of view. And for that reason, their emotions are as strong as ever.
The following table provides suggestions for how your character awakened and became a Fallen.
Fallen's Awakening: 1d6 | Objective 1 | You were backstabbed by a most trusted friend, all because of money and glory. At your dying breath you swore to bring down everything they had built. 2 | Your daughter was taken away by a Hag, and you didn't stand a chance against it. Even in this new form, you must save her before it is too late. 3 | You made a promise or an oath and don't have any intention of breaking it, even after death. 4 | You were once a powerful king from a long forgotten past. At your deathbed you had promised to make your kingdom prosper, but it's long since been reduced to ashes. 5 | You discovered a dark secret, but were killed because of it. You must stop it before something bad happens. 6 | You died on a battlefield and broke your promise to return home. However, in this new form would they still love you?

trait.name: Uncertain Future
trait.text:
After a Fallen completes its quest, the sensation of emptiness emerges inside their mind and soul. The ones who were able to fulfill their quest may sometimes abandon their position as warriors and become hermits, isolating themselves from all the world around them, waiting for its end.
However, those who's hearts still want to fight for something continue their position as warriors until outmatched by a stronger opponent, finally being able to rest once and for all.

trait.name: Fallen Names
trait.text:
Fallen usually either keep the name they had in life, either to show they're back from the grave or to be remembered. But some of them choose different names that exude power or intimidate others, always resembling their subspecies.
Examples of such names are: Haunt, Lilith, Reaper, Revan, Shadow, Wraith.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:

A creature of nightmares. A Fallen. A monstrosity with a body of flames. He cuts left, then right. But still he hears the footsteps behind him. And in no time, the monster's light covers his whole body. This was the end. He knew it.
The vampire delighted himself, draining the blood from the foolish adventurer that thought that she alone could end his empire. As he did, the blood's taste felt foul, even for an undead. The corpse of the fallen warrior started to convulse with shadows darkening her skin, covering her completely. The vampire jumped a few steps back, trembling in fear knowing what was happening. Even in this new form, you must save her before it is too late. 3 | You made a promise or an oath and don't have any intention of breaking it, even after death. 4 | You were once a powerful king from a long forgotten past. At your deathbed you had promised to make your kingdom prosper, but it's long since been reduced to ashes. 5 | You discovered a dark secret, but were killed because of it. You must stop it before something bad happens. 6 | You died on a battlefield and broke your promise to return home. However, in this new form would they still love you?

trait.name: Uncertain Future
trait.text:

However, those who's hearts still want to fight for something continue their position as warriors until outmatched by a stronger opponent, finally being able to rest once and for all.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
The Mousefolk have a deep love of art, literature, song, and craft, and will often spend a lifetime perfecting their trade. True masterworks are rarely seen by the outside world, instead they are preserved and passed through the generations. To be a keeper of lore and heritage is among the highest honors and greatest responsibilities in Mousefolk culture.
The Mousefolk who do not end up learning a trade will often put their skills to use pursuing esoteric knowledge, training as defenders, spiritual leaders, rangers, covert agents, or they might even travel the world as an adventurer-for-hire.
Source: DnDBeyond Unearthed Arcana (Homebrew), GmCorsair (Homebrew)

trait.name: Virtuous And Headstrong
trait.text: Despite their generally flighty appearance, mousefolk are a very honorable people. They believe strongly in personal honor, less so in the idea that the actions of others can impugn that honor. When a mousefolk makes a mistake, especially one that causes harm to others, they will work hard and at long lengths to correct that mistake.

trait.name: Mousefolk Names
trait.text:
When a Mousefolk is old enough to read, they are taken by an elder to the clan's archives to study the lore and histories of their people. After several years, the individual is allowed to pick their own name, either adopting the name of a past hero, or inventing a new name for themselves.
Male Names: Aengus, Ashwin, Aynselle, Boris, Byrnstan, Celanawe, Colin, Demitri, Elric, Esegar, Finn, Gregory, Joseph, Luke, Martin, Matthias, Mattimeo, Odric, Seyth, Thom, Waldwin
Female Names: Baeylie, Caley, Clove, Daewn, Dalla, Eda, Elis, Gale, Ingrid, Kearra, Mariel, Millicent, Moira, Nola, Rona, Rosalee, Sayble, Serra, Sylvia, Veira
Historical Names: Abershaw, Bluebell, Dalgill, Faolan, Garrow, Gamilon, Grimwold, Hannidy, Larkin, Sloan, Taryn, Tenny, Tinble, Toller, Vidar, Walmond

trait.name: Age
trait.text: A Mousefolk reaches adulthood at the age of 5 and lives to be about 40 years old.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Most Mousefolk are neutral, and tend towards good. They try to keep the conflicts of the other races at arm's length, but display remarkable ferocity when their friends, families, or communities are threatened. A reverence for nature and life is close to the heart of Mousefolk, and they are loath to take a life if it can be avoided. They prefer to live quiet and unassuming lives, giving honest work for honest pay.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Mousefolk grow between 2 and 2 1/2 feet tall and weigh about 25 pounds. Your size is Small.

trait.name: Keen senses
trait.text: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.

trait.name: Mousefolk weapon training
trait.text: You have proficiency with the rapier, shortsword, shortbow, and handaxe.

trait.name: Nimble Dodge
trait.text: When attacked by an Attack of Opportunity, you may use your reaction to impose disadvantage on that attack.

trait.name: Artistry
trait.text: You gain proficiency with one type of artisan's tools or one musical instrument

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and Squeak Speak. Mousefolk place great value on the written accounts of their legends and histories, and encourage everyone to keep journals and records of their deeds. Almost all Mousefolk speak Common to converse with the people on whose lands they dwell or through which they are traveling.

To be a keeper of lore and heritage is among the highest honors and greatest responsibilities in Mousefolk culture.
The Mousefolk who do not end up learning a trade will often put their skills to use pursuing esoteric knowledge, training as defenders, spiritual leaders, rangers, covert agents, or they might even travel the world as an adventurer-for-hire.
Source: DnDBeyond Unearthed Arcana (Homebrew), GmCorsair (Homebrew)

trait.name: Virtuous And Headstrong
trait.text: Despite their generally flighty appearance, mousefolk are a very honorable people. They believe strongly in personal honor, less so in the idea that the actions of others can impugn that honor. When a mousefolk makes a mistake, especially one that causes harm to others, they will work hard and at long lengths to correct that mistake.

trait.name: Mousefolk Names
trait.text:
When a Mousefolk is old enough to read, they are taken by an elder to the clan's archives to study the lore and histories of their people. After several years, the individual is allowed to pick their own name, either adopting the name of a past hero, or inventing a new name for themselves.
Male Names: Aengus, Ashwin, Aynselle, Boris, Byrnstan, Celanawe, Colin, Demitri, Elric, Esegar, Finn, Gregory, Joseph, Luke, Martin, Matthias, Mattimeo, Odric, Seyth, Thom, Waldwin
Female Names: Baeylie, Caley, Clove, Daewn, Dalla, Eda, Elis, Gale, Ingrid, Kearra, Mariel, Millicent, Moira, Nola, Rona, Rosalee, Sayble, Serra, Sylvia, Veira
Historical Names: Abershaw, Bluebell, Dalgill, Faolan, Garrow, Gamilon, Grimwold, Hannidy, Larkin, Sloan, Taryn, Tenny, Tinble, Toller, Vidar, Walmond

trait.name: Age
trait.text: A Mousefolk reaches adulthood at the age of 5 and lives to be about 40 years old.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Most Mousefolk are neutral, and tend towards good. They try to keep the conflicts of the other races at arm's length, but display remarkable ferocity when their friends, families, or communities are threatened. A reverence for nature and life is close to the heart of Mousefolk, and they are loath to take a life if it can be avoided. They prefer to live quiet and unassuming lives, giving honest work for honest pay.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Mousefolk grow between 2 and 2 1/2 feet tall and weigh about 25 pounds. Your size is Small.

trait.name: Keen senses
trait.text: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.

trait.name: Mousefolk weapon training
trait.text: You have proficiency with the rapier, shortsword, shortbow, and handaxe.

trait.name: Nimble Dodge
trait.text: When attacked by an Attack of Opportunity, you may use your reaction to impose disadvantage on that attack.

trait.name: Brave
trait.text: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

trait.name: Speak with small beasts
trait.text: Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas with Small or smaller beasts.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and Squeak Speak. Mousefolk place great value on the written accounts of their legends and histories, and encourage everyone to keep journals and records of their deeds. Almost all Mousefolk speak Common to converse with the people on whose lands they dwell or through which they are traveling.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Burrowrats live in complex subterranean networks, comprised of burrows and tunnels. They are almost always expanding their burrows, so they are adept at navigating earth, and their life underground gives them more sensitive vision in the dark.
Source: DnDBeyond Unearthed Arcana (Homebrew), StrayChowChow (Homebrew)

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Ratfolk reach maturity quickly, but live fairly short lives. A ratfolk is considered an adult by the age of 3 and rarely live past 30.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Ratfolk societies are often chaotic and disorganized, with no clear laws or hierarchy. Most ratfolk are chaotic.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Your size is Small.

trait.name: Superior Darkvision
trait.text: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

trait.name: Underfoot
trait.text: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
trait.text: You can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of your turns.

trait.name: Earth Walk
trait.text: You can move across difficult terrain made of earth or stone without expending extra movement.

trait.name: Tunneler
trait.text: You suffer no penalties due to squeezing into a smaller space.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and speak Ratfolk. Ratfolk is a verbal language consisting of chitters and other rat-like noises. There is no written component of Ratfolk.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Sewerats are settlement parasites, living in the sewers or dumps of other races. They live off of waste and refuse, though they are occasionally known to steal food from homes in the city.
Source: DnDBeyond Unearthed Arcana (Homebrew), StrayChowChow (Homebrew)

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Ratfolk reach maturity quickly, but live fairly short lives. A ratfolk is considered an adult by the age of 3 and rarely live past 30.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Ratfolk societies are often chaotic and disorganized, with no clear laws or hierarchy. Most ratfolk are chaotic.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Your size is Small.

trait.name: Darkvision
trait.text: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

trait.name: Underfoot
trait.text: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
trait.text: You can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of your turns.

trait.name: Sewer Resilience
trait.text: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and speak Ratfolk. Ratfolk is a verbal language consisting of chitters and other rat-like noises. There is no written component of Ratfolk.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Wildrats, in contrast to Burrowrats, live on the surface. They most commonly inhabit forests, but have been found in almost all biomes. Their vulnerability to predators forces them to be as stealthy as possible, and they have perfected communication with fellow animals to survive.
Source: DnDBeyond Unearthed Arcana (Homebrew), StrayChowChow (Homebrew)

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Ratfolk reach maturity quickly, but live fairly short lives. A ratfolk is considered an adult by the age of 3 and rarely live past 30.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Ratfolk societies are often chaotic and disorganized, with no clear laws or hierarchy. Most ratfolk are chaotic.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Your size is Small.

trait.name: Darkvision
trait.text: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

trait.name: Underfoot
trait.text: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
trait.text: You can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of your turns.

trait.name: Speak with Small Beasts
trait.text: Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas with Small or smaller beasts.

trait.name: Mask of the Wild
trait.text: You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and speak Ratfolk. Ratfolk is a verbal language consisting of chitters and other rat-like noises. There is no written component of Ratfolk.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
The imposing brutan are a proud group of saurians that originate from nomadic tribes found in the lush deserts of the far reaches of the world. Seen as monsters by most due to their stature and weaponized biology, the brutan face many difficulties acclimating to new cultures. Oftentimes, mercenary groups will raid brutan caravans for supplies and captives, taking advantage of their low numbers. Despite this, the brutan remain an honorable people and usually reciprocate kindness when it is given. Although their honorable ways have also coerced some tribes to enact vengeance against those who have wronged their people.
Source: rattatooey (Homebrew)

trait.name: Creature Type
trait.text: You are a humanoid. You determine your appearance and whether you resemble any of your kin.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: You are Large.

trait.name: Bite
trait.text: You have a powerful fanged maw that you can use to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with it, the strike deals 1d6 + your Strength modifier piercing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike. Immediately after hitting, you can try to grapple the target as a bonus action. Until this grapple ends, you can't bite another target.

trait.name: Focus
trait.text: You have advantage on saving throws to avoid or end the frightened condition on yourself.

trait.name: Natural Armor
trait.text: Your body is covered in thick scales and bony plates. While you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class is 13 + your Constitution modifier.

trait.name: Primal Vigor
trait.text: When under pressure, your predatory instincts grant you guidance in combat. When you hit a target with a melee attack, you can cause the target to take extra damage equal to your proficiency bonus. While you are missing half or more of your hit points, you also gain temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, but you can use it no more than once per turn. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for your character.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
When I was a child I sought out the guardian of my people's ancestral forest. I wandered for days deep within the woods, and I am certain that I never have found the ancient gardener had he wished to remain hidden from me. His true name was too much long for me to comprehend, but he allowed me to call him Whiproot. For a year and a day he taught me the ways of the wood, slowly nurturing my druidic potential. Sometimes I still see those ancient green eyes in my dreams. Though I have grown old, I know that the gardener is still out there in the forest of my people, quietly singing to himself as he tends to the trees. -Zumug, Archdruid of the North
Source: LaserLlama's New & Alternate Player Races v2.0.0 p. 2 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Elder Gardeners
trait.text: Deep in the forests of the world dwell a forgotten people, the Entlings. They are the ancient caretakers of the forest who awoke at the dawn of the world. To many, they are creatures of myth and folktale, reclusive tree-like people with skin like bark and hair that resembles tree-tops and verdant gardens. Though these gardeners are few in number, they are very much real, though they prefer to be forgotten. Most Entlings will happily spend their exceptionally love lives tending to the large swaths of wilderness under their care, learning the names of every root, flower, and tree under their protection.

trait.name: Shepherds of the Forest
trait.text: Entlings care deeply for the plants under their care, and often watch them grow from seedling to fully mature plants. They prefer to spend their lives in quiet harmony with nature, only occasionally interacting with other mortals. They carefully maintain the natural order of the ecosystems they dwell in, culling creatures that grow to numerous, nurturing those on the brink of extinction, and all the relationships in between. Though rarely roused to action, Entlings who strike out into the world often do so to protect the forests under their protection. Though slow to anger, their fury knows no bounds when evil or blight threatens the groves that they have raised from seedlings. Entlings who leave the forest usually find it difficult to fit in amongst civilized settlements, and usually struggle to understand the norms and customs of normal folk. Entlings who become adventurers most often train to defend the wild as a ranger or join a local Circle of druids.

trait.name: Entling Names
trait.text: Due to their long lifespans and relaxed disposition, Entling names are often exceptionally detailed stories that can take days to explain. Often, the Entlings that interact with mortals will adopt the name of their favorite plant, tree, or flower.

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Entlings are considered to be adults around the age of 100, and can live to be over 1000 years old if they spend their lives in peace. Hasty Entlings that take up the stressful live of adventuring can shorten their lifespan by up to 500 years.

trait.name: Creature Type
trait.text: You are both Humanoid and Plant.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Entlings are a naturally peaceful folk that care for all living things, and they tend towards good alignments.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Entlings reflect the forests and plants they tend to, and thus come in all shapes and sizes. Your size is Medium.

trait.name: Gardener's Lore
trait.text: You gain proficiency in the Nature skill, and you can make a Wisdom (Nature) check whenever you would normally make an Intelligence (Nature) check.

trait.name: Natural Magic
trait.text: You know one cantrip of your choice from the Druid spell list. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for it.

trait.name: Photosynthetic
trait.text: You don't need to eat or drink so long as you are exposed to sunlight for 1 hour each day. To gain the benfits of a long rest, you must spend at least 6 hours in an inactive, motionless state, though you remain aware of your surroundings. In this state, you can see and hear as normal, and you appear to be a normal tree unless closely inspected.

trait.name: Shepherd of the Forest
trait.text: Through sound and gestures, you may communicate simple ideas with plants of all kinds.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common, and your choice of either Druidic, Sylvan, or Elvish.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
From atop the great walls of Hammerdeep I watched as the young half-dwarf disappeared into the swamp. Based on talent along, he should have been chosen as apprentice to the master smith of the great walled city. Sadly, due to his human mother, the young smith had been passed over for a less skilled, but full-blooded dwarf. I always admired how he refused to stoop to the menial work delegated to half-dwarves, and I was determined to help him earn the right to use the clan name of his father. I knew the task would be dangerous, especially to a dwarf with so little experience as a warrior, but if the he could succeed in slaying the young dragon that had taken up residence in the swamp, the elders would have no choice but to accept him. -Lord Thorin Stormfist Hero of Hammerdeep
Source: LaserLlama's New & Alternate Player Races v2.0.0 p. 3 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Dwarven Tradition
trait.text: Half-dwarves often showcase the best of both of their parents' heritage. Like dwarves, they will usually place high value on honorable conduct and reputation. And, although they are not considered full members of their respective clans, most half-dwarves will go to great lengths to win acceptance, or prevent bringing shame upon the clan of their dwarven parent. Often, when a clan has risky or nefarious business to take care of, they will task a half-dwarf with taking care of things. That way, should things go poorly, dishonor is not brought upon a full-blooded member of the clan. Seeking to belong, half-dwarves will go to great lengths to gain the favor of their dwarven relatives. Refusing to deny their human heritage, it is very difficult, and requires great feats of service for a half-dwarf to be recognized by the elders as a member of the clan.

trait.name: Human Innovation
trait.text: From their human heritage, half-dwarves bring the spark of innovation and desire to create a personal legacy. Far more individualistic then other dwarves, their innate desire to push boundaries drives them to innovate on the craftsmanship of both dwarves and humans, often ignoring the traditions of master artisans. Due to their dedication and ingenuity, half-dwarven products are often sought after by those with an eye for quality. Unfortunately, half-dwarves are rarely accepted into dwarven guilds due to dwarven tradition and customs.

trait.name: Half-Dwarf Names
trait.text: Half-dwarves are often given dwarven first names, but either take the last name of their human parent, or adopt the name Stone. Being officially recognized as a member of their clan is seen as the highest honor to be bestowed on a half-dwarf.

trait.name: Half-Dwarves of the Multiverse
trait.text: Half-dwarves can exist in any setting that includes both humans and dwarves. A hardy folk, they often sprout up wherever these two races meet. In the Dark Sun setting, half-dwarves are known as Mul, and sadly, due to their natural fortitude and stamina they are prized as gladiators and laborers.

trait.name: Ability Score Increases
trait.text: Your Constitution score increases by 2, and one other ability score of your choice increases by 1.

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Half-dwarves mature at the same rate humans do and reach adulthood around the age of 20. They live much longer than humans however, often close to 200 years.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Half-dwarves often share the lawful bend of their dwarven heritage, but some favor more chaotic ways of life. Most tend toward good as well, with a strong sense of fair play and a belief that everyone deserves to go wherever they please and share in the benefits of a life free from tyranny.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Half-dwarves are about the same size as humans, if a little shorter and stockier. You stand between 4 1/2 and 5 1/2 feet, and weigh around 200 pounds. Your size is medium.

trait.name: Darkvision
trait.text: Thanks to your dwarven blood, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. However, you can't discern color when in darkness, only shades of gray.

trait.name: Hardy
trait.text: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

trait.name: Natural Craftsman
trait.text: You gain proficiency with one set of artisan's tools of your choice. You add double your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make that uses those tools.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common, Dwarvish, and one additional language of your choice. Half-dwarves often learn the language of peoples they work with.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
When the warrior awoke, he knew something was different. The last thing he remembered was the feeling of numbness that washed over him as the acid breath of the great dragon consumed him. Almost instinctively, the warrior took stock of his surroundings he seemed to be in some sort of laboratory. Across from the table on which he lay stood a mirror, and gazing upon his reflection shook him to his core. The warrior's skin was a pale blue and his eyes flickered with a strange maroon light. As he took survey of himself, he seemed stronger, almost as if some strange new power was flowing through his veins. -Lord Tormund Shadowfall Paladin of the Sacred Fire
Arcane Magen are embodiments of raw magic, and serve as assistants in arcane research.
Source: LaserLlama's New & Alternate Player Races v2.0.0 p. 4 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Arcane Creations
trait.text: While most spend their lives searching for purpose, Magen come with that purpose woven into their very being. Created by powerful mages to fulfill a specific duty, Magen physically resemble adult humanoids, but pale bluish skin and maroon eyes set them apart. Their innate magic allows them to live without the food, air, and water required by mortals, but their innate magic makes them susceptible to anti-magic effects.

trait.name: Loyal Servants
trait.text: While the typical Magen is fiercely loyal to their creator, even to death, those that become adventurers are those that have thrown off the yoke of servitude. When you create a Magen, consider why they struck out into the world. Are they seeking a purpose greater than the duty they were created for?

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Magen are created to resemble adult humanoids, and they show no signs of deterioration due to age. Their upper lifespan is speculated to be around 500 years old.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Magen are lawful by nature, and most often reflect the alignment of their creator, be it good or evil.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Magen are roughly the size of an adult human, ranging from five to six feet tall. Your size is Medium.

trait.name: Arcane Construct
trait.text: You can be damaged by anti-magic spells. If you are targeted by dispel magic, you take 1d6 force damage per each level of the spell slot expended to cast it. You also take 1d6 force damage each time you enter, or start your turn, within an anti-magic field (or other similar effect).

trait.name: Born of the Weave
trait.text: You have advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
trait.text: You do not require air, food, or drink.

trait.name: Arcane Nature
trait.text: You know one cantrip of your choice from the wizard spell list. When you reach 3rd level, you learn one 1st-level wizard spell, and when you reach 5th level, you learn one 2nd-level wizard spell. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells, and you can cast each spell once per long rest without expending a spell slot, after which you must expend one of your own spell slots to cast it again.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common, and one other language of your choice. Most Magen are imbued with the knowledge of a language spoken by their creator.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:

Almost instinctively, the warrior took stock of his surroundings he seemed to be in some sort of laboratory. Across from the table on which he lay stood a mirror, and gazing upon his reflection shook him to his core. The warrior's skin was a pale blue and his eyes flickered with a strange maroon light. As he took survey of himself, he seemed stronger, almost as if some strange new power was flowing through his veins. -Lord Tormund Shadowfall Paladin of the Sacred Fire
Warrior Magen are created to as the guardians for places of great arcane power.
Source: LaserLlama's New & Alternate Player Races v2.0.0 p. 4 (Homebrew)

When you create a Magen, consider why they struck out into the world. Are they seeking a purpose greater than the duty they were created for?

trait.name: Optional Rule: Magen as a Lineage
trait.text:
If your character is brought back by a mage, or has their body magically enhanced, you can adopt the Magen race to replace your original player race.
If you replace a race with this lineage, you keep any climbing, flying, or swimming speed granted by your original race, along with any skill proficiencies granted by your original player race.

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Magen are created to resemble adult humanoids, and they show no signs of deterioration due to age. Their upper lifespan is speculated to be around 500 years old.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Magen are lawful by nature, and most often reflect the alignment of their creator, be it good or evil.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Magen are roughly the size of an adult human, ranging from five to six feet tall. Your size is Medium.

trait.name: Arcane Construct
trait.text: You can be damaged by anti-magic spells. If you are targeted by dispel magic, you take 1d6 force damage per each level of the spell slot expended to cast it. You also take 1d6 force damage each time you enter, or start your turn, within an anti-magic field (or other similar effect).

trait.name: Born of the Weave
trait.text: You have advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
trait.text: You do not require air, food, or drink.

trait.name: Athletic Frame
trait.text: You were created in peak physical condition. You are proficient in the Athletics skill.

trait.name: Martial Nature
trait.text: You are proficient with light and medium armor and with two marital weapons of your choice.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common, and one other language of your choice. Most Magen are imbued with the knowledge of a language spoken by their creator.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Every fairy I've ever met has been irritating beyond belief, and I cannot fathom why the Prince of Winter hasn't expelled the little buggers from his court completely. Sure, their small stature and tiny wings allow them to access places that I certainly couldn't, and their skill with illusion magic does come in handy more often than I'd like to admit. Actually, now that I think about it, they do seem to have their uses. Maybe I need to give these tricksters another chance.
-Sir Tumnus Longfinger Champion of the Winter Court
Source: LaserLlama's New & Alternate Player Races v2.0.0 p. 4 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Fleeting Fancies
trait.text: Fairies may be the most spontaneous creatures in existence, constantly moving from one interest to the next as something new or exciting catches their attention. They are curious to a fault, and love to experience new things whenever they have the chance. When a fairy puts their mind to something, they put everything they have into their pursuits. Though it may not last, the determination of a fairy knows no bounds.

trait.name: Servants of the Fey Court
trait.text:
All Fairies begin their lives in the service of one of the Courts of the Feywild, and the Archfey they serve is the closest thing many of them will have to a parent. The longer a fairy spends in the presence of an Archfey, the more they start to resemble them. Those who have spent lifetimes in the service of a Fey Court often come to resemble miniature versions of Archfey, in appearance and manner. While in the Feywild, Fairies stop maturing, both physically and emotionally, when they reach adulthood, allowing them a strange perpetual immortality.
The fairies who reject a life of unchanging servitude most often do so to become adventurers on the material plane, where they can age and develop normally. Fairy adventurers often pursue their knack for illusion magic as bards, wizards, or sorcerers, though some strike pacts and become warlocks.

trait.name: Fairy Names
trait.text: Due to their whimsical nature and ever-changing interests, Fairies will change their name spontaneously when a mood takes them. Fairies usually adopt the name of a particularly beautiful natural phenomena or powerful emotion; Aurora, Dewdrop, Sunrise, Rainbow, Joy, Serenity, or Glee.

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Fairies reach adulthood a year and a day after their birth, and do not age further in the Feywild. While in mortal realms they age normally and can live to be 100 years old.

trait.name: Creature Type
trait.text: You are both Humanoid and Fey.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Fairies hail from the courts of many different Archfey, but they are almost universally Chaotic in alignment.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Fairies only stand a few inches in height, the largest of which stand almost a foot tall. Your size is Tiny. As a Tiny creature, you can only wield weapons that have the Light property, and you cannot wear armor or clothing unless it is specifically sized to fit a creature of your stature.

trait.name: Dainty Wings
trait.text: So long as you are not wearing medium or heavy armor, you have a flying speed of 30 feet and can hover, but you cannot fly, or hover, more than 10 feet off the ground. At 5th level, this 10 foot height restriction is lifted.

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
trait.text: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can't put you to sleep.

trait.name: Fey Magic
trait.text: You know the minor illusion and faerie fire spells. You can cast faerie fire without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can cast it this way again. You can also cast this spell using any spell slots you have. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak, read, and write Common and your choice of either Sylvan or Elvish.

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Paul rivers enlisted in the town guard the day he turned sixteen. None of the villagers thought that this was a particularly good idea, but no one had the heart to turn the boy away. And after all, the village hadn't been attacked by monsters in almost ten summers. Paul trained with the rest of the guardsmen, and despite his boyish personality, he was a natural with the sword and spear. Over the next few months he grew in skill and strength, and by the following summer, Paul was able to best every warrior in the village. Just before harvest, a group of evil cultists descended upon the small hamlet. They stole everything of value, and burned anything that couldn't be stolen. At the town's most desperate moment, with the survivors cowered in the armory, the cult's champion issued a challenge. A duel to the death for the lives of the remaining villagers. Without saying a word, Paul drew his sword and stepped forward to defend his home. -Berthold Cornersnatch Traveling Bard and Storyteller
In most worlds, humans are the most numerous of the mortal races, and their grit and adaptability allow them to succeed in all but the most hostile environments. trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Paul rivers enlisted in the town guard the day he turned sixteen. None of the villagers thought that this was a particularly good idea, but no one had the heart to turn the boy away. And after all, the village hadn't been attacked by monsters in almost ten summers. Paul trained with the rest of the guardsmen, and despite his boyish personality, he was a natural with the sword and spear. Without saying a word, Paul drew his sword and stepped forward to defend his home.
-Berthold Cornersnatch Traveling Bard and Storyteller

trait.name: Description
trait.text:
Palefang stepped forward into the circle that was already forming around him. He had left the village two moons ago as a hatchling, determined to return and prove his strength. He now sought to challenge the aging chieftain for his position as leader of the clan. The rival lizardfolk he had slain earlier that day had strengthened his reputation enough that the chieftain did not think it disgraceful to accept his challenge. If he won, Palefang would wrest control of the clan, and the other hatchlings would be forced to respect him. As the circle of lizardfolk closed around him and the chieftain, Palefang drew his bone dagger. The chieftain let out a guttural hiss and dropped his cloak from his shoulders, revealing a scaled body covered in scars. The noise of the tribe grew louder and louder in his ears, and for the first time in a long time, Palefang knew fear.
-Captain Rufus Hogback Retired Adventurer
Above all else, Desert Dwelling lizardfolk are cowards. After hundreds of years of being hunted by desert predators these frilled reptilians are few in number, living in tribes less than ten members strong. They always settle in locations with many escape routes should they be attacked while resting.
Source: LaserLlama's New & Alternate Player Races v2.0.0 p. 7 (Homebrew)

trait.name: Tribal Warriors
trait.text:
Lizardfolk are a people unlike any other; feeling no emotion, yet fiercely loyal to their tribe. Their need to prove themselves in battle makes them dangerous neighbors, and they are constantly involved in tribal warfare. Their culture of war has prevented them from advancing past their primitive ways.
Unlike most humanoids, they do not form familial bonds, instead bonding with their tribe. Any lizardfolk would risk their life to protect the hatchlings of their tribe. Even the females that lay clutches of eggs view all of the hatchlings, even those they didn't hatch themselves, as their children.

trait.name: Honor and Violence
trait.text:
Lizardfolk society is governed by a strict caste system based on personal reputation. Lizardfolk increase their standing by overcoming enemies that are their equal, or better. They have no interest in fighting the weak, and they will stop at nothing to test their skill in battle against more powerful foes.
Lizardfolk view their lives, and all of their actions, through this lens. After they hatch, they have one year to accomplish enough great deeds to earn their place as an adult member of their tribe. If they fail to meet this expectation they are exiled from the tribe or killed in honor duels by their clutchmates.

trait.name: Lizardfolk Names
trait.text:
Lizardfolk hatchlings are named for their appearance. If they survive to adulthood they are given a new name based on how they established their reputation. Lizardfolk are always looking to overcome greater obstacles and earn new names.
Hatchling Names: Blackclaw, Dreadspine, Greenscale, Heavystep, Longtooth, Quickfinn, Rotfang, Widemaw.
Adult Names: Bonecrusher, Firewalker, Heartsplitter, Kingbreaker, Lightthief, Trollslayer, Wyrmeater.

trait.name: Age
trait.text: Lizardfolk reach maturity around 1 year of age and are almost always slain in battle before the age of 60.

trait.name: Alignment
trait.text: Most lizardfolk are neutral in their outlook. They see the world as a harsh place of predators and prey.

trait.name: Size
trait.text: Lizardfolk are bulkier and taller than humans, often standing well over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

trait.name: Bite
trait.text: Your fanged maw is a natural weapon which deals piercing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier.

trait.name: Cunning Artisan
trait.text: As part of a short or long rest, you can use a blade or dagger to harvest bone and hide from a Small or larger creature to create one of the following objects: a shield, a club, a javelin, or 1d4 darts or needles.

trait.name: Natural Armor
trait.text: You have tough scales. When unarmored, your Armor Class is equal to 13 + your Dexterity modifier. You can still use a shield and gain the benefits of this trait.

trait.name: Quick Feet
trait.text: Your movement speed increases by 5 feet, and you have advantage on initiative rolls when not surprised.

trait.name: Frilled Defense
trait.text: You gain proficiency in Intimidation, and you have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks you make against creatures with an Intelligence of 6 or lower.

trait.name: Languages
trait.text: You can speak both Common and Draconic.
